metadata.title: W3Schools.com
metadata.Keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website
metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: The median value is the value in the middle, after you have sorted all the values.
content.html: The median value is the value in the middle, after you have sorted all the values.

content.text: If we take a look at the values of the wt variable (from the mtcars data set), we will see that there are two numbers in the middle:
content.html: If we take a look at the values of the wt variable (from the mtcars data set), we will see that there are two numbers in the middle:

content.text: Note: If there are two numbers in the middle, you must divide the sum of those numbers by two, to find the median.
content.html: Note: If there are two numbers in the middle, you must divide the sum of those numbers by two, to find the median.

content.text: Luckily, R has a function that does all of that for you: Just use the median() function to find the middle value:
content.html: Luckily, R has a function that does all of that for you: Just use the median() function to find the middle value:

content.code_html:
Data_Cars <- mtcars

median(Data_Cars$wt)
